title: whether the SHAP will retrain the model which it evaluates? on the sub-dataset that contains part of features
body:
I have a question about the SHAP.

After I train a model, eg. neural networks on my dataset, I use SHAP to evaluate.
Does SHAP use the same idea of the calculation of Shapley Value?

What I mean is the **SHAP will enumerate all combination of features** (human-understanding) on the training dataset but do not retrain the model waited for being evaluated on new sub-dataset (i am not sure whether it is on training or testing, it matters a lot!????), and get the shape value finally?


Is it the process of calculating the weight for each feature?

I will like to show a simple example to explain my question:
Assuming the dataset (age, gender, occupation), label is (employed, unemployed).
I use the Neural network as my model to do binary classification.
After i trained my model, i use SHAP to evaluate.

When I use the SHAP, all my features will be combined in different orders. It contains 8 orders: only [age], only [gender], only [occupation], [age, gender], [age, occupation], [gender, occupation], [age, gender, occupation]. 

In order to calculate the shapley value, the testing (or training? I'm confused here. A question raised here) inputs only containing sub-features like [gender, occupation] will be given the trained model. Then the prediction ratio will be the score of this feature combination [gender, occupation], right? This is my second question.

The SHAP will not train the model again based on sub-training (or sub-testing dataset)? This is my third question.
